reviewText: Would use again.
No subtitles for the deaf and hard of hearing. Not even closed captions. In this day an age of electronics? Selling it for more than a two cents is a scam!
Waited years for this to be released on DVD. Couldn't be happier (unless of course, they had released it sooner). Until now I had to put up with my VHS recording of this movie (with commercials).

Andy Griffith as Sheriff -- interesting casting?

Griffith made 3 TV movies with the idea that it might become a new series.  It didn't.  He plays a small-town sheriff in all three films.  This story is a little convoluted and not very satisfying when the "mystery" is solved.  The ending seems somewhat forced -- like, okay, let's wrap this movie up.

That being said, the acting is good, and if you liked the other two movies, you will probably like this one -- just not as much. The other two are Winter Kill (1974) and Deadly Game (1977 -- released same year as this one).  Both are better than this one.

For a guy who started out with a hillbilly comedy routine on radio, he turned out to be a pretty good actor, certainly an enduring one, who was able to constantly play essentially the same role(s) all his life.
GOOD MOVIE
Good Andy Griffith movie
I really like the movie, I am very satisfied
If you like Matlock then I believe you'll like this DVD. It needs to be apart of your Library if you are a Andy Griffith fan.

If you don't like Andy Griffith at the top of his game then I don't recommend this movie. The movie is a bit slow but that's the way the script was written. The cast works really well together and there is no one better suited to play a small town chief of police  Andy Griffith. After all he's been doing it since the fifties. If you like this movie I recommend you check out some of his other made for television movies.
One of my favorite classic Andy Griffith movies.  Had to have it!

I hadn't heard of this movie of his, though if it's similar to "Winter Kill", I will probably like it.  The thing that made me curious after seeing the plot description is that Andy's character is Abel Marsh, the same as James Garner's character in "They Only Kill Their Masters".  It seems unlikely it would be a coincidence and maybe it's supposed to be a sequel, though the towns are different (Eden's Landing in the Garner movie and Jasper Lake in this one).  Just thought I'd make these comments for the folks who have seen the movie.
no flaws in disk, good movie uf you like Andy
i saw this movie 20 years ago & i had 2 have it in my personal stock

The copy I received, though brand new, skipped around terribly in 2 of my DVD players, making the DVD unwatchable. So a replacement copy was sent to me. The replacement copy skipped around even worse and in completely different places than the first copy I received. In the end, I had to return this copy too and got a refund.

The movie freezes up part way through.

Andy Griffith stars as the sheriff when he discovers that something strange is going on in his town.  This series of three movies will leave you begging for more, but these were the only three he made.  If you like the JESSIE STONE series, these are along the same line and will keep you focused from the beginning to the end of the story.  They are not shown on television anymore, but the one time they did show them I watched all three.  It took me awhile to find them on line, but thankfully I did.

This film and several others were shot at Big Bear Lake, California, in the 70s.  Location fabulous, story line enjoyable, Andy Griffith always fun to watch.
